TimeAmerican International Group Inc.May 15Jan 16Sep 16May 17Jan 18 US:AIG $50 $55 $60 $65 Marking another milestone, AIG AIG, -2.77%  said it’s now reduced U.S. government-authorized support in the company by more than $152 billion as a result of the repayment of the Federal Reserve’s so-called Maiden Lane III LLC loan. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York recently completed auctions of Maiden Lane III assets, meaning AIG has fully repaid the non-recourse loan using cash flows from interest and principal payments as well as liquidation of assets. The New York-based company, which received billions in federal support at the height of the 2008-2009 financial crisis, noted the Fed earned nearly $3 billion from the previous sale of the Maiden Lane II portfolio and said the central bank “could earn as much” when the Maiden Lane III portfolio has been fully liquidated. The U.S. Treasury still owns about $30 billion in AIG common stock as the government’s remaining investment. Maximum support for AIG authorized by the government reached $182 billion in 2008, of which $21 billion was unused or expired, the company said. Net earnings for the May quarter are pegged at 30 cents to 32 cents a share, with profit on an adjusted basis seen in a range of 44 cents and 46 cents a share. Quarterly sales are expected to range between $560 million and $565 million. Special charges taken against results for the latest quarter are expected to total about $13.5 million, AAR said. Repurchases will be made from time to time in open-market or private transactions using available cash and cash generated from operations, the company said. content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Small companies are often overlooked, unappreciated and hard to understand. That's just how Eric Cinnamond likes them. "Small-cap companies are really unique," said the manager of Intrepid Small Cap Fund ICMAX, -0.22% "Companies like this don't move with the market." Going against the herd was the driving force behind the three stocks Cinnamond recommended in a late April interview for MarketWatch's column "The Stockpickers." See full story. Over a treacherous 13-week stretch that challenged investors' patience and rattled their confidence, the stocks Cinnamond chose were notable standouts, gaining 13.6% on average after he named them. In particular, shares of a specialized telecommunications company and a discount retailer connected to give Cinnamond MarketWatch's Stockpicker of the Quarter award. In winning, Cinnamond surpassed 18 other investment professionals featured in MarketWatch's column "The Stockpickers" in the second quarter of 2008. In these stories, investors select three stocks whose performance is then tracked over the following 13 weeks -- the last period of which began June 27 and ended Sept. 26. Favored stocks can be domestic or international, covering all market sizes, investment styles and industry sectors. Each stock picker is reviewed on how selections performed from the closing price on the nearest trading day before the story is published through the closing bell on the nearest trading day 13 weeks later. The grim investing climate in the second quarter and over the summer hit most managers featured in The Stockpickers especially hard. Double-digit losses in shares of well-known, established companies were not uncommon. Cinnamond found success at the other end of the spectrum, investing in smaller companies in niche businesses that he prized for being cash-rich, solidly managed and not widely followed. Intrepid Small Cap slid 1.3% from the close on April 21 through the end of trading on July 21. That result was better than the 2.5% decline for the small-cap focused Russell 2000 Index RUT, -1.99% in that period, and well ahead of its small-value category's 5% average loss, according to investment researcher Morningstar Inc. The fund's investment in Applied Signal Technology APSG rallied sharply. Shares of the maker of telecommunications and signal processing gear soared 31.7% in the 13 weeks after Cinnamond recommended it. Meanwhile, the weakening economy was a boon for Family Dollar Stores Inc. FDO, +7.10% an off-price retail chain whose shares rose 14.1% in the 13 weeks. A third stock, Mocon Inc. MOCO a maker of instruments used to detect, measure, and analyze gases and chemicals, finished the period down 5%. Patterson-UTI Energy The energy sector has been in the crosshairs of the slowing global economy, and these former market darlings have been so beaten up they're attracting Cinnamond's attention. The fund didn't own energy stocks at the end of the third quarter; now the sector represents about 8% of assets. "Everyone loved energy with oil at $140 a barrel," Cinnamond said. Now, with oil prices just above $60, "everyone hates it." That's reason enough for value buyers like Cinnamond to go digging. One company he's unearthed is oil-services outfit Patterson-UTI Energy Inc. PTEN, -4.20% Day rates for oil rigs have declined, taking down Patterson's core drilling business and its shares. Shares of Patterson-UTI Energy closed Monday at $12.63 -- a fraction of their 52-week high of $37.45 set in July. Patterson's shares are oversold, Cinnamond said. He sees a cash-rich company that pays a dividend of around 5% and a stock that should trade closer to $35 a share. "I'm not going to time when energy is going to turn," Cinnamond said. "But I know Patterson is going to take market share because there's a lot of leveraged companies out there that aren't going to make it." Gencor Industries Cinnamond is also upbeat about Gencor Industries GENC, -1.86% which produces asphalt for road construction. The stock has been routed as the U.S. economy sputtered and the outlook for infrastructure and other construction projects darkened. Shares of Gencor finished Monday's session at $6.50; the stock fetched $32.88 in May. But for a value investor, Gencor is appealing, Cinnamond said. Gencor's recent $59 million market capitalization values the company at a discount to the cash on its balance sheet, which alone is worth about $8 a share, he noted. Plus, the company owns a parcel of land in Orlando, Fla. that isn't being factored into the share price, Cinnamond said. In addition, that cash hoard allows Gencor to operate without borrowing, keeping the company financially sound, the fund manager said. And the stock isn't widely covered. "Most of the companies we follow aren't relying on the credit markets," Cinnamond said. "I'd rather own a company that isn't dependent on the generosity of Wall Street." Oil-Dri Corporation of America Oil-Dri Corporation of America ODC, -3.01% operates a line of branded consumer products -- though its target customers are of the feline variety. The company is the market leader in cat litter, including the well-known Jonny Cat and Cat's Pride brands. It also sells private-label products to Wal-Mart Stores and makes the Fresh Step brand litter for Clorox. Most investors wouldn't give much thought to a company like Oil-Dri, which is one reason why the stock is part of Cinnamond's portfolio. Oil-Dri's business stems from its vast reserves of clay, which is used not just for cat litter but for agriculture, machine shops, cleaning oil spills and other absorbent tasks. What's hurt Oil-Dri recently is the high price of natural gas that helps dry clay, Cinnamond said, adding that the additional expense has chopped into the company's profit margins. The shares traded at $16.28 on Monday, down from a 52-week high of $23.60 last December. Cinnamond said he has a high degree of confidence in Oil-Dri's ability to navigate the obstacles it faces, and accordingly he's made it a prominent fund holding. "Most of the companies we own," he said, "are in relatively stable end markets." Applied Signal Technology As for the stocks Cinnamond recommended in late April, Applied Signal Technology is still among the Intrepid fund's biggest holdings. "It generates quite a bit of cash, and nothing's really changed except their cash has gone up," Cinnamond said. "They've got some growth ahead of them and orders are very strong. I think there's a near-term catalyst on earnings." The fund manager tapped Applied Signal at $11.32 a share. After 13 weeks, the stock traded at $14.91. The shares ended Monday's session at $18.02. Family Dollar Stores Cinnamond bought into Family Dollar Stores earlier this year when retail stocks were trampled and the fund manager thought the company's shares had been unfairly punished. He recommended Family Dollar Stores at $20.36 a share, and 13 weeks later the stock traded at $23.24. But that price was close to Cinnamond's fair value; he sold the position in early August. Shares of Family Dollar Stores closed at $26.94 on Monday. "We're very disciplined about selling when a stock hits our valuation," Cinnamond said. "It's back on my wish list, but the valuation is not there." Mocon Mocon continues to be one of Cinnamond's favorites. The gas and chemical firm is a "very profitable business," he said, and its shares, he added, are "really cheap for a company with 20% operating margins." The company has a market value of just $47 million but is a "market leader," he added. Its spending more on marketing, sales and international growth, and yet has enough cash to pay an attractive dividend of around 4%, Cinnamond noted. The shares didn't fare so well in the 13 weeks after Cinnamond recommended them, slipping to $10.64 from $11.20. On Monday, shares of Mocon finished trading at $8.94. But given Cinnamond's focus on value, Mocon remains a top holding. "Things overshoot, but that's what creates opportunity," he said. "I love it when stocks fall because I'm able to buy them at a cheaper price." The company said a recent decision to provide self-clearing to trader equities helped create the improvement. On Tuesday the company's stock dropped 34 cents to $6.21. Goodyear to post Q4 rise on higher prices, settlement (7:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. GT, -2.29% said it expects fourth-quarter earnings per share between 55 cents to 65 cents a share, as raw material price increases were offset by higher prices and by strong acceptance of its new products, on sales of $4.8 billion, which would be a company record. Goodyear said the quarter would include a $157 million gain from a previously disclosed insurance settlement as well as $22 million from a lawsuit settlement, while also seeing charges of $26 million pre-tax on liability for discontinued products and $11 million from asset sales. Operating income is expected to double in its European Union business, rise by about 50 percent in Latin America and improve 15 percent in chemical products, while its North American Tire business is expected to see its third straight positive operating income. Goodyear also said it plans to refinance $3.3 billion in credit facilities. Goodyear says a restatement of its third quarter 2004 due to out-period adjustments won't have a material impact on 2004 net income, and it'll need to make additional disclosures about Australian affiliate South Pacific Tyres before filing its financials. Martha Stewart swings to Q4 net loss, rev. drops 15% (7:47 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Inc. MSO, +0.00% swung to a 14 cent a share loss from continuing operations in the fourth quarter as group revenue contracted 15 percent to $60.2 million. In the year-ago period, the group posted income of 5 cents a share. Its net loss for the period was $7.3 million. Looking ahead, the media group said: "As March approaches, all of us at MSO... are eager to welcome Martha back. Both station affiliates and advertisers have embraced MSO's new syndicated television program featuring Martha Stewart. Come fall, we're certain viewers will too." ProAssurance Q4 profits handily top estimates (7:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Net Income for ProAssurance Corp. PRA, -2.27% posted Wednesday fourth quarter net income of $21.5 million, or 69 cents a share compared with $13.8 million, or 46 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. The specialist of medical liability insurance said revenues for the quarter climbed to $211.9 million versus $199.2 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 61 cents a share on revenue of $210 million. ProAssurance shares fell 3 percent, to $37 in trading Tuesday. Anteon International Q4 net income jumps 189% (7:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Anteon International Corp. ANT, +3.36% reported fourth-quarter net income of $16.96 million, or 45 cents per share, up 189 percent from $5.86 million, or 16 cents per share in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed 25 percent to $350 million. The Fairfax, Va. military contractor was expected to earn 44 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial. The company forecasted first-quarter earnings per share of 43 cents or more and 2005 earnings of $1.89 or more. The company is expected to earn 44 cents per share in the first quarter and $1.90 for the year. Shares fell 29 cents to $35.27 on Tuesday. Century Business sees 05 rise after Q4 profit fall (7:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Outsourcing group Century Business Services Inc. CBIZ said fourth-quarter net income fell to $1.7 million, or 2 cents a share, from $2.3 million, or 3 cents a share, while revenue edged up to $125.5 million from $122.9 million and same-unit revenue rose 0.9 percent. Earnings from continuing operations were steady at 3 cents a share. For 2005, it sees revenue growth between 5 percent and 8 percent and expects to lift continuing operations EPS by 20 percent to 25 percent from the 21 cents it had in 2004. LCA-Vision raises 2005 profit outlook; Q4 net up 121% (7:26 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- LCA-Vision Inc. LCAV reported fourth-quarter net income of $4.86 million, or 23 cents per share, up from $2.2 million, or 12 cents, earned in the final three months of 2003. The laser-vision correction provider's operating income jumped to $5.63 million from $2.25 million in the year-ago quarter. Revenue reached $32.72 million, up 58 percent from $20.76 million. Analysts, on average, had been expecting LCA-Vision to post quarterly earnings of 14 cents per share on revenue of $30 million. Procedures volume totaled 24,224 in the latest quarter, up 51 percent. The company also revised higher its profit outlook for 2005, with LCA-Vision now projecting a range of $1.00 to $1.05 per share. Shares of LCA-Vision lost 11 cents to end at $26.94 in Tuesday's trading. Speedway Motorsports Q4 earns rise, top expectations (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Speedway Motorsports TRK, -2.02% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $13.5 million, or 31 cents a share, up from $11.1 million, or 26 cents a share in the same period a year ago and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 27 cents a share. Revenue rose 5 percent to $88.5 million from last year's $84.6 million, as growth in event-related and NASCAR broadcasting revenue offset a decline in admissions. For 2005, the motorsports entertainment promoter expects earnings of $2.15 to $2.25 a share, surrounding analyst forecasts of $2.22 a share, and revenue of $500 million to $525 million. The stock closed Monday down 74 cents at $37.65. American Woodmark's Q3 earns decline to $7.1M vs $7.7M (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Woodmark AMWD, -5.49% reported third-quarter earnings of $7.1 million, or 42 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $7.7 million, or 46 cents per share. Sales rose 12 percent in the latest three months to $183.2 million from $162.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The Winchester, Va., kitchen cabinet maker attributed the sales increase to higher unit volume and an improved product mix. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 54 cents per share in the January period. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of 53 to 59 cents per share in the fourth quarter, saying it expects continued pressure on margins from rising material and freight costs. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 69 cents per share in the April period. The stock closed Tuesday at $40.75, down 2 percent. Apparel maker Russell Q4 net falls, while sales climb (7:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Russell Corp. RML, +0.00% said fourth-quarter earnings fell to $10.3 million, or 31 cents a share, from $14.5 million, or 44 cents a share, while sales rose 10.5 percent to $334 million, or a 3 percent comparable sales rise. The sportswear maker said it took a 6 cents a share impact from the dilution of Huffy Sports, severance costs and incremental expenses from Sarbanes-Oxley compliance. Russell reiterated its $1.55 to $1.65 per share view for 2005 and said sales should rise 15 percent to 17 percent to $1.5 billion to $1.52 billion. In the first quarter, it expects an EPS between 5 cents and 8 cents. Ciena Q1 earns loss narrows, sales jump 43% (7:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Network equipment provider Ciena Corp. CIEN, -2.16% reported a fiscal first-quarter loss that narrowed to $57 million, or 10 cents a share, from $76.6 million, or 16 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue for the period jumped 43 percent to $94.7 million, fueled by strong growth in core optical transport, core switching and data networking. Excluding one-time items, Ciena would have posted a loss of 5 cents a share, in line with the forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, Ciena said it expects revenue to rise 5 percent to 7 percent sequentially in the second quarter. Lowe's cautious on Q1 outlook; Q4 profit rises 30.6% (7:14 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Lowe's Cos. LOW, -4.38% posted net earnings of $508 million, or 64 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended Jan. 28, up from $407 million, or 50 cents, earned in the same period last year. The home-improvement retailer's quarterly sales reached $8.55 billion from the prior year's $7.252 billion, as comparable-store sales rose 6.9 percent. Wall Street, on average, had been looking for a profit of 59 cents per share on sales of $8.401 billion. For the current year, Lowe's is projecting earnings of 75 cents to 77 cents in the first quarter and $3.25 to $3.34 per share for the 12 months, as opposed to analysts' average estimates of 80 cents and $3.34 per share, respectively. Total sales are projected to rise 15 percent for the quarter and 17 percent for the year, the company said. Shares of Lowe's lost $1.22, or 2.1 percent, to end Tuesday's trading at $57.53. Young Broadcasting Q4 revs higher on political revenue (7:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Young Broadcasting Inc. YBTVA said revenue for the fourth quarter grew 19.1 percent to $63.8 million, driven by $13.8 million of net political revenue as compared with $2.2 million in the same period last year. Net loss narrowed to $1.3 million, or 6 cents a share, from $13.2 million, or 67 cents per share. Hearst-Argyle TV Q4 net rises, sees lower Q1 revs (7:04 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hearst-Argyle Television Inc. HTV said net income for the fourth quarter rose to $39.6 million, or 41 cents per share, from $33.9 million, or 36 cents a share, meeting Thomson First Call broker expectations. Revenue increased 16 percent to $221 million. It said it will "evaluate" the resumption of its share buyback program. First-quarter earnings are expected to fall to between 11 cents to 13 cents a share, from 19 cents a share in same quarter last year, and revenue in the first quarter is expected to fall 4 percent to 5 percent, reflecting the absence of around $10 million of political advertising and a $2.5 million reduction in T.V. network compensation. Jack in the Box posts strong Q1; lifts FY05 outlook (7:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Jack in the Box Inc. JBX, -6.28% reported first-quarter earnings of $25.4 million, or 68 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $14.4 million, or 39 cents per shaer. The San Diego fast-food restaurant operator attributed the strong results to new products and seasonal promotions that lifted same-store sales for the sixth straight quarter. Revenue rose to $738.6 million in the latest three months from $669.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 66 cents per share in the January period. The company also said its board has approved a $65 million increase in its buyback program. Looking ahead, Jack in the Box sees earnings of 50 cents per share for the second quarter. It also lifted its outlook for the full year to earnings of $2.43 per share from its previous projection for a profit of $2.33 per share. The stock closed Tuesday unchanged at $33.55. Big Lots Q4 net falls, will restate '02-04 accounts (6:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Retailer Big Lots Inc. BLI in preliminary results due to an accounting error, said fourth-quarter net income fell to $57.7 million, or 51 cents per share, from $85.3 million, or 73 cents a share, higher than broker forecasts of 48 cents a share according to Thomson First Call. Comparable store sales fell 1.3 percent on "continued softness in customer traffic," but net sales rose 3.9 percent to $1.38 billion. Big Lots sees fiscal 2005 earnings to be between 54 cents and 60 cents a share, based a comparable sales increase of 3 percent to 4 percent. It also said that, as a result of errors made in accounting some leasing transactions, it will restate its accounts for 2002, 2003 and 2004. The corrections will reduce net income by less than $2 million per year, or 2 cents per share, for each of the fiscal years. PRA Intl swings to 22c profit with revs up 8.3% (6:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PRA International, PRAI the Reston, Va., clinical research firm, reported that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit of 22 cents a share from a year-earlier loss as total revenue rose 8.3 percent. Net income was $4.9 million, or 22 cents a share, against a loss of $928,000, or 6 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted for certain expense, net was 23 cents against the 6-cent loss. Revenue advanced to $77.9 million from $72 million. Service revenue increased 16 percent to $71.2 million. The company affirmed its estimate, issued in January, that this year it would earn $1.18 to $1.22 a share as service revenue climbed to a range of $308 million to $312 million from $277.5 million in 2004. The company's 2006 estimate is $1.37 to $1.43 a share of profit as service revenue reaches $345 million to $355 million. PRA shares rose 30 cents, or 1.3 percent, on Tuesday to $22.69. EnCana's Q4 operating earnings 81%; 2-for-1 split set (6:20 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- EnCana Corp. ECA, -5.36% posted fourth-quarter operating earnings of $573 million, or $1.23 per share, up from $316 million, or 68 cents, earned in the same period in 2003. The Canadian-based energy developer's quarterly revenue, including discontinued operations, reached $4.407 billion from $2.85 billion. EnCana's net earnings amounted to $2.58 billion, or $5.55 per share, up from $426 million, or 91 cents, in the year-earlier fourth quarter. Earnings from continuing operations came in at $1.188 billion, or $2.56 per share, up from $447 million, or 96 cents. According to Thomson First Call, analysts' average estimates were for EnCana to earn $1.40 per share in the latest quarter on revenue of $3.02 billion. The company also said shareholders will vote April 27 on a board-approved 2-for-1 stock split. U.S.-traded shares of EnCana added $1.13, or 1.8 percent, to end Tuesday's dealings at $64.63. Canadian Natural Resources Q4 profits more than double (5:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil and gas explorer Canadian Natural Resources Ltd CNQ, -2.76% (CA:CNQ)said fourth-quarter earnings rose to $577 million, or $2.15 per share, from $250 million, or 93 cents a share, with quarterly production rising 16 percent. It's replaced 220 percent of production with new proved reserves in 2004. It said quarterly 2005 dividends will rise by 12.5 percent to 11.25 cents a share. Northwest Pipe posts strongest Q4, sees Q1 rev. fall (5:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Northwest Pipe Co. NWPX, +2.40% said it posted its highest quarterly sales and earnings in its history, with net profit up to $4.2 million, or 62 cents a share, from $1.4 million, or 20 cents a share, as sales rose to $80.3 million from $59.1 million. Looking forward, its water transmission revenue will be lower in the first quarter due to the timing of projects but should rise in the second quarter and remain strong the rest of the year. Tubular products sales volumes have slowed in the first part of 2005 but is expected to grow in the second and third quarters. Efunds Q4 profits rise, unveils $100m buyback plan (5:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Efunds Corp. EFD said fourth-quarter earnings rose to $11.3 million, or 22 cents a share, from $10.1 million, or 21 cents a share, while revenue fell to $130.5 million from $135.4 million on the sale of its ATM portfolio. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based electronic payments provider also approved a $100 million share buyback plan, though it can't buy back shares at more than $25 per share, and inked a $100 million credit facility. EFunds says 2005 revenue should rise 8 percent to 12 percent from its three remaining segments and net income should rise 17 percent to 22 percent. Toll Brothers Q1 beats Street, ups FY profit outlook (5:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Luxury homebuilder Toll Brothers TOL, -4.09% said net income in the first quarter to Jan. 31 rose to $110.2 million, or $1.33 per share, from $50.1 million, or 62 cents a share, beating broker expectations of $1.15 a share according to Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 67 percent to $999.1 million as "demand for luxury homes continues to outpace supply." It has raised its anticipated net income growth for the 2005 fiscal year to 60 percent, from its previous guidance of 40 percent, and now expects to deliver between 8,050 and 8,400 homes, an increase from its previous projection of 7,900 to 8,300 homes. UK BBA engineering cautious on H1 amid high mat. prices (2:55 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British aviation and materials technology group BBA(UK:BBA)cautioned that if raw materials prices remain at current levels "it will restrict profit growth in the first half of 2005." Overall, the group said it expects that "despite the issues with raw materials we are anticipating another year of strong operating cash flow in 2005." Underlying pre-tax profit eased to 128.1 million British pounds in 2004 from 130.5 million pounds in 2003, reflecting the weaker dollar and rising material costs. Sales from continuing operations rose 12 percent to 1.4 million pounds on a constant currency basis. The group is set to hike its dividend payout to holders by 5 percent for the year to 10.8 pence a share. Scottish &Newcastle '04 pre-tax profit up 11%, in line (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. brewer Scottish & Newcastle(UK:SCTN)Wednesday reported 2004 pre-tax profit up 11 percent to 373 million pounds on a comparable basis, even as sales grew only 1.7 percent to 4.99 billion pounds due a 32-percent cut in Finnish excise duty. The results came in toward the top end of the AFX News-compiled analyst forecasts for a profit in the range of 360 million to 380 million pounds. Organic growth in beer volumes was 4.5 percent. The brewer lifted its final dividend 2.5 percent to 13.75p a share. Looking ahead, the company said trading so far in 2005 was in line with recent trends in all major markets. Michael Page recruit: Mkt conditions improve in Europe (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. professional recruitment group Michael Page International(UK:MPI)said market conditions in Continental Europe "are improving, although they remain uncertain" as it posted an 18 percent rise in revenue for 2004 to 210.6 million British pounds. Profit before tax and exceptional items rose to 40 million pounds from 22.9 million a year ago. The group is set to hike its dividend payout to holders for the year to 4 pence a share from 3.4 pence in 2003. Looking ahead, it said: "The short term outlook is encouraging. Market conditions in the UK, Asia Pacific and The Americas are favourable and we plan to grow our businesses by increasing our headcount... In Continental Europe where market conditions are improving but remain uncertain, we will increase headcount in some of our businesses but no new office openings are planned for 2005." Pallet-maker Brambles H1 cont. sales up 5% at GBP 1.6bn (2:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British Pallet-maker Brambles(UK:BI)posted a 5 percent rise in sales from continuing operations for the half year ending Dec. 31 to 1.6 billion pounds. Profit ahead of tax and items rose 31 percent, it said, to 172 million pounds. Looking ahead, it said: "We are expecting good progress for both profit and cash generation for the full year." Egg 2004 pre-tax loss widens to GBP 107 mln vs. 34 mln (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British online bank Egg(UK:EGG), majority-owned by insurer Prudential Plc.(UK:PRU) PUK, -2.18% posted a 106.7 million pound pre-tax loss for 2004, widening from the 34.3 million pound loss in 2003 largely reflecting losses and charges for its French operations. Group operating income rose 19 percent to 505 million pounds. Egg said it was encouraged by a "good recovery" in the second half after rising competition and uncertainy over the potential sale of Prudential's stake impacted the first half of 2004. Costs for exiting France are in line with its 113 million pound provision, it said. Looking ahead, it said: "We are in the process of broadening our product range and are delighted with our initial success in sales of general insurance policies." Peugeot 2004 earnings fall, sales higher on new models (2:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French automaker Peugeot(FR:012150)said net income under French GAAP standards in 2004 fell to 1.36 billion euros, or 5.6 euros per share, from 1.5 billion euros, or 6.14 euros, in line with expectations from JCF Group. Under IFRS, its net income was 1.68 billion euros. Sales rose 4.7 percent to 56.8 billion euros, with sales in the fourth quarter rising 6.6 percent. Sales in its automobile division increased 4.8 percent to 45.8 billion euros on higher global sales and increased sales of newer models offsetting sales declines in Western Europe. Anglo American 04 net up 83%, sees strong China growth (2:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Metals group Anglo American AAUK (UK:AAL)on Wednesday said 2004 profits rose 83 percent to $2.91 billion, with revenue climbing 27.6 percent to $31.8 billion, on strong global growth and commodity prices. Its headline earnings, a widely-viewed measure of profitabilty for the company, rose 59 percent to $2.689 billion, slightly lower than AFX News-compiled analyst forecasts of $2.72 billion. It upped its final dividend by 31 percent to bring its total dividend up 30 percent for the year at 70 cents. For 2005, it said China continues to grow strongly though leading indicators from OECD countries point to some slowing of industrial output; on the suply side, output is set to increase, and much will depend on industry "capital discipline" amid high commodity prices. content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Among the shares likely to see active trading in Wednesday's regular session are AutoZone Inc. and Merck & Co. AutoZone AZO, -5.84% the No. 1 U.S. auto parts chain, is expected to post a first-quarter profit of $1.44 a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Merck & Co. MRK, -2.35% said late Tuesday that it is establishing a committee to review its handling of the controversial withdrawal of its popular painkiller Vioxx from the market. See full story. Wednesday's watch list Alliance Semiconductor ALSC said it named Jeff Parsons chief financial officer, replacing Ronald Shelton, effective Jan. 15. Alloy Inc. ALOY reported it swung to a third-quarter profit of $1.6 million, or 4 cents a share. A year ago, the New York-based marketing and retail company reported a loss of $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter was $110 million vs. $105.8 million a year earlier. See After Hours. Amgen Inc. AMGN, -3.56% said its board has approved up to $5 billion to buy back its common stock. The biotechnology company said it has about $968 million remaining under its previous repurchase plan. See full story. Atlas America ATLS, -0.61% said it earned $6.9 million, or 52 cents a share, up from $5.1 million, or 48 cents a share, last year. Pro-forma earnings were 56 cents a share, beating the average analyst estimate of 48 cents a share. Avon Products AVP, -3.87% said it sees fourth-quarter earnings of 61 cents a share and 2005 earnings of $1.95 to $2 a share. It expects earnings a share for 2005 to 2007 to increase at least 10 percent a year. It also plans to discontinue toy sales and certain Beyond Beauty products lines during the second quarter of 2005, reducing Beyond Beauty sales by about $145 million and related profit by $15 million to $20 million during the quarter. Bob Evans Farms BOBE said its November same-store sales fell 1.3 percent from the same period last year, while its menu prices for the month increased about 1.9 percent. Casey's General Stores CASY, -1.31% reported second-quarter earnings fell to $11 million, or 22 cents a share, from $15.8 million, or 32 cents a share, a year ago. Total revenue for the quarter was $717.3 million vs. $611.6 million a year earlier. Central European Distribution Corp. CEDC said it has named Christopher Biedermann chief financial officer, effective Jan. 17. Biedermann will replace Neil Crook. Dave & Buster's DAB, +0.23% an adult entertainment and dining chain, is expected to report third-quarter earnings of a penny a share. Duke Energy DUK, -0.56% has agreed to pay $207 million to settle claims with California parties demanding refunds for charging unjust rates for electricity during the power crisis in 2000 and 2001, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said. See full story. Fortune Brands FO, +2.99% said it will terminate its "poison pill" provision Dec. 31, three years before its originally intended expiration date. See full story. Furniture Brands International FBN said it sees fourth-quarter earnings coming in at the lower end of its previously announced outlook of 36 cents to 38 cents a share because of softer orders and activity at its upper-end and middle-priced companies. G-III Apparel GIII, -5.28% reported third-quarter earnings of $9.9 million, or $1.33 a share, down from $11.4 million, or $1.50 a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $114.9 million, compared with $125.5 million in 2003. The company lowered its earnings outlook for 2005 to 18 cents and 23 cents a share, down from its previous estimate of 38 cents to 43 cents a share. The company said it expects revenue for the year to be about $215 million. Geac Computer Ltd. GEAC reported second-quarter earnings of $15.2 million, or 17 cents a share, up from $10.3 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $106 million, down from $111 million. General Dynamics GD, -2.35% said its Electric Boat unit won a $5.6 million contract modification for nuclear-submarine work for the U.S. Navy. General Dynamics said the contract, which is expected to be completed by September 2008 could be worth up to $1.1 billion over five years if all options are exercised and funded. GenTek Inc. GETI said plans to pay a $7 one-time dividend on Dec. 27 for shareholders as of Dec. 17. It said the dividend is tied to proceeds from the sale of the company's KRONE operations. Innkeepers USA Trust KPA said it signed an agreement to buy three hotel assets from three unaffiliated sellers for about $55 million. Intergraph Corp. INGR, -2.19% said it named Kevin Twomey, St. Joe Co.'s JOE, -2.65% COO and CFO, as an independent board member on its compensation and governance and nominating committees. JP Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, -3.12% said it has agreed to sell the Chase Home Finance manufactured housing loan portfolio to Vanderbilt Mortgage and Finance. Terms were not disclosed. JP Morgan Chase said the Chase Home portfolio is worth about $4 billion and expects the deal to close by Dec. 31. Korn/Ferry International KFY, -2.42% an executive recruitment firm, is expected to report earnings of 19 cents a share for the second quarter. Loews Corp. LTR, +2.78% said it plans to sell 10 million shares of Carolina Group stock in a public offering. The deal, run by Citigroup Global Markets and Morgan Stanley, will close by Dec. 13. McRae Industries MRIA MRIB, +0.00% said it is conducting a review of its fiscal 2004 financial statements as a result of inventory calculation errors. The company said it believes its inventory was overstated and the related costs of revenue were understated by about $1 million. McRae now expects net earnings of $3.1 million, as opposed to the previously reported $3.7 million. It said it will not file its 10-Q with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for the first quarter of 2005 until it has completed its review of 2004 results. Mercury Computer Systems MRCY, -1.90% said it has bought Momentum Computer Inc. for about $14 million in cash. The company said there is the potential for an additional $12 million in cash payments if Momentum achieves certain performance criteria. Net2Phone Inc. NTOP said its first-quarter loss was $8.2 million, or 11 cents a share. Last year, it earned $5.1 million, or 8 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter fell slightly to $20.3 million from $20.4 million, a year ago. Analysts had estimated a first-quarter loss of 11 cents a share and revenue of $22 million. See After Hours column. Oil-Dri Corp. ODC, -3.01% said its board has approved the buyback of an additional 500,000 shares and is also authorized to repurchase up to 550,904 additional shares. Pegasus Communications PGTVE said the Nasdaq granted its request for continued listing of its stock through Dec. 17. Pegasus said that if it files its second-quarter 10-Q with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission by Dec. 17, the deadline would be extended through Dec. 24 to permit the company's filing of its third-quarter 10-Q. Photronics Inc. PLAB, -4.24% said fourth-quarter revenue was $104.2 million with earnings of 7.9 million, or 21 cents a share, compared to revenue of $91.5 million and earnings of $3.1 million, or 10 cents a share, for the same period last year. Analysts expected earnings of 25 cents a share on revenue of $107 million. PNM Resources PNM, -1.05% it expects 2005 earnings to be in the range of $1.40 a share to $1.55 a share. It is also raising its quarterly dividend 15.6 percent to 18.5 cents a share, payable Feb. 18 to shareholders of record on Feb. 1. Portal Software PRSF which makes billing and subscriber management software, is seen reporting a third-quarter loss of 38 cents a share. Remec Inc. REMC posted a narrower third-quarter loss of $3.5 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with a loss of $4.1 million, or 7 cents a share, in the same period last year. See full story. Rohm and Haas Co. ROH, +0.42% said its board authorized a $1 billion stock repurchase of its common stock through 2008. The company also announced a fourth-quarter pretax restructuring charge of $18 million for cash severance and employee separation benefits affecting about 200 employees. It said it expects to save $27 million in 2005. The company also reaffirmed its fiscal 2004 revenue estimate of $7.2 billion and full-year earnings of $2.10 a share to $2.20 a share. Seagate Technology STX, -1.42% said strong demand across its product lines will bring revenue and earnings for its second fiscal quarter to higher-than-expected levels. See full story. Siebel Systems SEBL said it was making a push into the market for small and medium businesses. CEO Mike Lawrie said the move was a "key component" of the company's next phase of growth. Stewart & Stevenson Services SVC, -0.34% said it entered an agreement to sell its airline products business to Jacobson Partners, a private equity firm, for $60 million in cash, deferred consideration and the assumption of specified liabilities. The sale is expected to close in Jan. Taubman Centers TCO, -0.75% said it has increased its quarterly dividend 5.6 percent to 28 cents a share, payable Jan. 20 to shareholders of record on Dec. 31. Texas Instruments TXN, -3.61% narrowed its financial targets for its fourth quarter as demand appeared to be shaping up the way it had predicted two months ago. See full story. Toro Corp. TTC, -3.99% which makes lawn care products, is seen reporting a fourth-quarter profit of 21 cents a share. Unisys Corp. UIS, -6.74% said it expects fiscal 2004 earnings will come in at the low end of its outlook, as sales com in flat to slightly higher. See full story. Walt Disney Pictures DIS, -2.19% and Pixar Animation Studios PIXR said they are delaying the release of their final joint movie by eight months to coincide with the 2006 summer movie season. content: Koor Industries Q3 profit more than doubles (Corrects) (10:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Koor Industries KOR, +0.00% reported late Monday that third-quarter income more than doubled to $3 million, or 10 cents per American Depository Share, from $1.2 million, or 2 cents per ADS, a year ago. Net income for the quarter included a $9.6 million net capital gain from the sale of 16 percent of Knafaim Arkia and a $9.5 million charge following the impairment of a tax asset at Telrad Networks. Revenue for the quarter was $491.2 million vs. $412.8 million a year earlier. (Corrects to reflect degree of rise in profit) H&R Block reports $52.2M net loss in Q2 (Corrects) (7:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- H&R Block HRB, -4.01% reported a fiscal second-quarter net loss of $52.2 million, or 32 cents a share, late Tuesday and cut its full-year earnings guidance after income from its mortgage business slumped. A year earlier the company said it earned $10.4 million. The firm said it now expects to earn between $3.50 and $4 a share in its full 2005 fiscal year. Fiscal second-quarter revenue came in at $539.3 million, down 5.2 percent from last year, the firm added. (Corrects second-quarter per-share profit figure) Possis Medical Q1 earns up 13%, lowers 2005 outlook (6:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Possis Medical Inc. POSS reported late Tuesday that first-quarter earnings rose 13 percent to $2.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from $1.9 million, or 10 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $17.5 million vs. 15.6 million a year earlier. Possis said second-quarter earnings are expected to be in the range of 9 cents to 11 cents a share on revenue between $16 million and $17 million. The Minneapolis, Minn.-based company lowered its 2005 earnings outlook to between 40 cents a share and 54 cents a share on revenue between $66 million and $72 million. Previously, Possis said it believed 2005 earnings would be in the range of 57 cents to 62 cents a share on revenue between $75 million and $80 million. Starcraft Corp posts 68% drop in Q4 profit (6:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Starcraft Corp. STCR reported a 68 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings late Tuesday, hurt by amortization charges and a shift in its business mix, which had a negative effect on gross margins. The Goshen, Ind.-based automotive parts maker said it made $931,000, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $45.4 million. In the same period last year, Starcraft made $2.9 million, or 51 cents a share, on revenue of $42.9 million. SeaChange Int'l shares fall on Q4 outlook (5:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of SeaChange International SEAC, -4.80% fell 9.7 percent to $15.70 after the bell Tuesday after forecasting fourth-quarter results below analyst expectations. The company sees earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $41 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $44 million. The provider of video-on-demand systems and services reported third-quarter earnings of $5.5 million, or 19 cents a share, compared to $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share a year ago. Revenue rose to $42.6 million from $38 million last year. Oil-Dri Q1 profit, revenue fall (5:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Oil-Dri Corp. of America ODC, -3.01% said Tuesday after the bell that its first-quarter net earnings were $1.3 million, or 22 cents a share. Last year, the company earned $1.7 million, or 30 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter fell to $44.1 million from $46.3 million. The company said it sees fiscal 2005 earnings of $1.20 a share to $1.30 a share. Integrity Fin'l restates, swings to Q3 loss (5:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Integrity Financial Corp. IFCBE said Thursday after the bell that it has restated its results for the third quarter as a result of increases to its provision for loan losses. The bank holding company said it now has a third-quarter loss of $1.1 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with a previously reported profit of $1.4 million, or 30 cents a share. It said it increased the loan loss provision to about $4.9 million from $385,000. Loudeye stock lower in after-hours trading (5:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Loudeye Corp. LOUD shares slipped 8 percent to $1.41 in after-hours trading Tuesday after running up 38 percent in the regular session. After the close, the company said in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that it plans a 14 million share stock offering. The company also filed an amended 10-Q filing with the SEC that said the company lost 31 cents a share from January through September 2004, not 25 cents a share as had been reported earlier. Handleman Co. Q2 earns fall 17%; reaffirms '05 EPS view (4:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Handleman Co. HDL after the bell Tuesday reported second-quarter earnings of $8.2 million, or 36 cents a share, down 17.6 percent from restated earnings of $9.9 million, or 40 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $295.3 million, up from $269.9 million last year. The company reaffirmed its 2005 earnings from continuing operations forecast of $1.52 to $1.58 a share, though it's "cautiously optimistic" about sales for the second half of the fiscal year. Taubman Centers issues 2004 outlook (4:43 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Taubman Centers TCO, -0.83% said after the bell Tuesday that it expects to report 2004 funds from operations of $1.82 to $1.83 per share. The company forecast a loss of 21 cents to 14 cents per share for the year. For 2005, Taubman estimates that its recently completed $100 million 8 percent preferred stock offering will add 1 cent FFO per share and 2 cents per share to income. Sigma Designs Q3 earns beat analysts' estimates (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sigma Designs Inc. SIGM, -0.40% said Tuesday after the bell that its third-quarter net earnings were $525,000, or 2 cents a share. Last year, the company earned $149,000, or a penny a share. Revenue for the quarter fell to $7.7 million from $8.1 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call estimated a loss of 1 cent a share and revenue of $8 million. Coldwater Creek Q3 income up 68% (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Coldwater Creek CWTR after the bell Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings of $9.4 million, or 23 cents per share, up from $5.6 million, or 15 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $150.5 million, compared with $138.2 million in 2003. Gottschalk's narrows losses in Q3 (4:22 PM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Gottschalk's Inc. narrowed losses for the third quarter to $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with last year's loss of $2.6 million, or 20 cents a share. However, the results were worse than the 8 cents a share loss expected, on average, by analysts reporting to Thomson First Call. The small regional department-store retailer said total sales rose to $147.8 million, compared with last year's $145.2 million. Shares of Gottschalk's GOT, -5.00% ended the session at $8.43, up 16 cents, ahead of the news. NDCHealth Corp to take Q2 3c/shr restructuring charge (4:19 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- NDCHealth Corp. NDC said Tuesday after the bell that it will take a second-quarter charge of about $2 million, or 3 cents a share, for severance and costs related to the elimination of senior management positions. The company forecast net earnings from continuing operations of a penny to 5 cents a share and adjusted earnings from continuing operations of 4 cents to 8 cents a share. NDCHealth also said it has amended its senior secured credit facility in order to incur the restructuring costs to improve its operations and profitability. Michaels profit pops 11% in Q3 (4:12 PM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Michaels Stores Inc. said after the bell that it made $42.4 million, or 31 cents a share, for the third quarter, matching Wall Street's expectations. The results were up 11 percent compared with last year's $38.2 million, or 27 cents a share. The arts-and-crafts retailer rang up $799.9 million in sales, 6 percent above the year-ago period. However, the company tempered its fourth-quarter expectations to the low end of a range of 74-76 cents a share. At Thomson First Call, analysts were expecting, on average, a profit of 76 cents a share. Shares of Michael's MIK, -1.78% ended the session at $30.14, up 34 cents, ahead of the news. Analog Devices Q4 earns 34c, sales $632.1 mln (4:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Analog Devices ADI, -3.35% reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $132.3 million, or 34 cents a share, and sales of $632.1 million. During the same quarter last year, the company earned $88 million, or 23 cents a share, on sales of $557.5 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 33 cents a share on sales of $637 million, on average, according to Thomson First Call. Tech Data posts $37.8 million Q3 profit (4:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Tech Data TECD, -6.03% on Tuesday reported a third-quarter profit of $37.8 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenue of $4.8 billion. The technology products reseller beat the estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call who forecast a profit of 55 cents a share on $4.73 billion in revenue. Going forward, Tech Data expects to report a fourth-quarter profit between $42 million and $45 million, or 70 cents to 75 cents a share, on revenue in a range ot $5.15 billion to $5.3 billion. Fred's Inc. Q3 earnings fall 17% (4:10 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Fred's Inc. FRED, -6.02% on Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings of $7.5 million, or 19 cents a share, versus $9 million, or 23 cents a share, last year. Sales for the period were $349.1 million against $311.7 million a year ago, as same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, grew 3.6 percent. The Thomson First Call consensus estimates were for earnings of 19 cents a share on sales of $350.3 million. In recent dealings Fred's shares gained 51 cents to $19.20. NYSE posts Q3 loss on higher legal, governance expenses (2:39 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- The New York Stock Exchange reported a third-quarter net loss of $1.6 million vs. net income of $6.9 million in the year-ago costs as increased revenue failed to compensate for higher legal and corporate governance expenses. Average trading volume was 1.33 billion shares, down from 1.36 billion as revenue climbed to $264 million from $262.7 million on increased listing fees. InterDigital Comms ups Q4 royalty revenue forecast (12:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- InterDigital Communications Corp. IDCC, -2.31% said Tuesday it has increased it royalty-revenue outlook for the fourth quarter to a range of $33.3 million to $33.6 million. The wireless technology provider previously forecast royalty revenue in excess of $30 million. The company cited "solid" sales of its 2G and 3G products by key licensees for the increased outlook. Escalon Medical posts lower Q1 earns, higher rev (12:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Escalon Medical Corp. ESMC, -6.67% on Tuesday reported first-quarter earnings of $115,899, or 2 cents per share, down from $623,156, or 15 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $5.3 million, compared with $3.4 million in 2003. Mobile TeleSystems posts higher Q3 results (11:55 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Mobile TeleSystems OJSC MBT, +0.61% on Tuesday reported third-quarter income of $338.3 million, up from $155.7 million a year ago. The Russia-based mobile phone operator posted revenue of $1.09 billion, compared with $722.4 million in 2003. Limited Brands declares special dividend (9:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Limited Brands LTD, +0.52% on Tuesday declared a special dividend of $500 million, or about $1.23 a share, to be paid Jan. 4 to shareholders as of Dec. 22. Additionally, the company disclosed the preliminary results of its $2 billion modified Dutch tender offer that expired at midnight, Nov. 22 ET. Limited said 88.3 million common shares were tendered at $29 a share and the company expects to purchase just under 68 million of those shares at $29 a share. Limited's stock closed unchanged Monday at $26.88. RCG Companies Q1 loss widens (9:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - RCG Companies Inc. RCG, +1.44% reported a first quarter loss Tuesday of $7.7 million, or 37 cents per share, compared with a loss of $900,000, or 7 cents per share in the same period last year. Revenue from consolidated operations rose to $56.8 million from $15.7 million a year ago. Shares of the travel and tour operator gained a penny to $1.04 Monday. Eaton Vance Q4 net rises (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Asset manager Eaton Vance said it earned $37.9 million, or 55 cents per share in the e fourth quarter, compared to $28.7 million, or 41 cents per share a year ago. Revenues in the latest quarter were $173.6 million versus $143.4 million a year ago. The average estimate of Wall Street analysts polled by Thomson First Call was 52 cents per share. Eaton Vance shares added 40 cents on Monday to $40.15. Brown-Forman Q2 earns rise, top expectations (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Brown-Forman Corp. BF.B, -2.36% reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of $102.6 million, or 84 cents a share, up from $88.2 million, or 72 cents a share in the same period a year ago, due primarily to strong performances by its premium spirits, particularly its Jack Daniels brand whiskey. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 79 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 8 percent to $724.5 million, but fell shy of the $754.8 million expected by analysts. The company narrowed its to fiscal 2005 earnings forecast to $2.38 to $2.43 a share from $2.35 to $2.43 a share. The stock closed Monday up 65 cents at $47.95. Duckwall-Alco Q3 swings to loss (8:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Duckwall-ALCO Stores, Inc. [s; duck] said its third quarter results swung to a loss as it reported as deficit of $46,000, or a penny per share, versus net earnings of $523,000, or 12 cents per share a year ago. Net loss for the most recent quarter included a net loss from discontinued operations of $256,000, or 6 cents per share compared with a net loss from discontinued operations of $7,000, or nil per share a year ago. Duckwall shares fell 60 cents to $16.90 on Monday. Deere posts Q4 income five times above 2003 level (8:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Agricultural equipment maker Deere & Co DE, -3.55% reported fourth quarter net income Tuesday of $356.7 million, or $1.41 per share, compared with $70.6 million, or 27 cents per share a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 99 cents per share on average for the quarter ended October 31. Revenue rose 32 percent to $5.21 billion from $3.38 billion a year ago. Shares fell 55 cents Monday to $68.71. Dollar Tree Q3 income down 12% (8:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Dollar Tree Stores Inc. DLTR, -1.40% on Tuesday said third-quarter earnings fell 12 percent to $31.9 million, or 28 cents a share, from $36.2 million, or 31 cents a share, last year. Sales for the period advanced 8.8 percent to $724 million against $665.2 million a year ago, as same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, inched up 0.7 percent. The Thomson First Call consensus estimates were for earnings of 28 cents a share on sales of $725.5 million. Shares were up 26 cents to $28.35 in pre-market trading Tuesday. ValueVision International reports wider Q3 loss (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- ValueVision VVTV on Tuesday reported a third-quarter net loss of $34.6 million, or 94 cents per share, compared with a net loss of $2.8 million, or 8 cents per share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $144 million from $150 million. The company took an $11.3 million charge for asset impairments after the loss of a partnership contract at its FanBuzz unit, and a $3.3 million charge for the elimination of positions within the company. The Minneapolis-based operator of the ShopNBC home shopping network was expected to report a loss of 70 cents per share, according to a survey of analyts by Thomson First Call. Shares of ValueVision Media rose 50 cents to $11.70 on Monday. Worldwide Restaurant Q3 profit improves (8:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Worldwide Restaurant Concepts FSZ, -0.09% Tuesday unveiled second-quarter net income of $900,000, or 3 cents per share, up from $300,000 or a breakeven per share result in the year-earlier period. The operator of Sizzler and other restaurants said its quarterly revenues strengthened to $79.4 million from $76.3 million. On Monday the stock rose 4 cents to $3.20. Signet Group Q3 comparable-store sales rose 2.8% (8:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - UK-based jewelry retailer Signet Group SIG, -7.04% Tuesday reported that its third-quarter overall comparable-store sales rose by 2.8 percent, while same-store sales in the U.S. increased by 3.5 percent. The company's third-quarter net income before taxes rose 9.1 percent to 8.4 million British pounds. On Monday in U.S. trade the stock fell 5 cents to $19.80. Wind River swings to a gain on revenue increase (8:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Wind River WIND, +1.61% reported third-quarter net income of $2.26 million, or 3 cents per share vs. a loss of $6.9 million, or 9 cents per share, on a 21 percent rise in revenue. Fourth-quarter earnings are expected to be 3-5 cents per share vs the forecast of 5 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company matched the forecast of 3 cents per share for its third quarter. Revenue was $60 million, up from $49.6 million. Shares of Wind River rose 37 cents to $14.18 on Monday. Tweeter Home takes another Q4 loss (7:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Tweeter Home Entertainment Group TWTR, -2.79% Tuesday announced a fourth-quarter loss from continuing operations of $10.1 million, or 42 cents per share, unchanged from the company's year-earlier loss figures. Quarterly revenue from continuing operations decreased to $176 million from $182 million in the same period last year. Comparable store sales decreased 3.5 percent, with much of the decrease occurring in the Southeast as a result of the hurricanes and other weather issues. On Monday shares of the Canton, Mass. electronics retailer fell 19 cents to $6.32. S&K Famous Q3 net rises (7:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- S&K Famous Brands Inc. [s; skfb] said Tuesday its net income for the third quarter ended October 30 was $157,000 or 6 cents per share, compared to $92,000, or 4 cents per share a year ago. Total sales for the quarter were $42.6 million compared to $40.3 million for the same quarter of last year, the company said. Same-store sales for the third quarter rose 2.5 percent. S&K Famous shares rose a penny Monday and closed at $15.72. CB Richard Ellis reaffirms 2004 earns view, 2005 to top (7:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- CB Richard Ellis Group CBG, +0.00% reaffirmed its 2004 earnings forecast, excluding special items, of $1.50 to $1.55 a share, vs. the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.55 a share. For 2005, the provider of commercial real estate services expects earnings of $1.80 to $1.90 a share, which is above current analyst projections of $1.75 a share. The stock closed Monday up 27 cents at $26.05. Heinz Q2 profit climbs 3.9% (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- H.J. Heinz Co. HNZ on Tuesday said second-quarter net income increased 3.9 percent to $199 million, or 56 cents a share, versus $191.5 million, or 54 cents a share, last year. Sales for the period advanced 5.2 percent to $2.2 billion from $2.09 billion a year ago. The Thomson First Call consensus estimates were for earnings of 59 cents a share on sales of $2.17 billion. Heinz stock closed up 95 cents to $38.39 Monday. H-P sees job cuts shaving 4c/shr off earns in H1 2005 (7:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Hewlett-Packard HPQ, -4.01% said it expects planned job reductions across it's businesses to shave 4 cents a share off earnings in the first half of 2005. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it expects job cuts to cost a total of $200 million in the period. Shares ended Monday up 12 cents at $20.20. World Wrestling Q2 earns fall, miss forecasts (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- World Wrestling Entertainment WWE, -3.05% reported fiscal second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $3 million, or 4 cents a share, down from $16.8 million, or 25 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 13 cents a share due to lower-than-anticipated attendance at its domestic live events and pay-per-view buys. Revenue fell 11 percent to $83.9 million, amid a 13 percent drop in revenue from its live and televised businesses. The media and entertainment company expects fiscal 2005 earnings of 46 to 50 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 55 cents a share. Revenue is expected to be between $345 million to $355 million. The stock closed Monday up 52 cents at $13.40. New York & Co. swings to Q3 loss (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- New York & Co. NWY, +3.55% on Tuesday said charges caused the retailer to swing to a third-quarter net loss of $4.6 million, or 10 cents a share, versus year-ago earnings of $5.8 million, or 10 cents a share. Sales for the period rose 8.5 percent to $242.3 million from $223.4 million last year. Excluding charges, earnings per share were 23 cents against the Thomson First Call-derived estimate of 20 cents. Shares closed down 1 cent to $20.14 Monday. Houston Exploration to restate earns (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Houston Exploration THX, +26.67% Tuesday said it will have to revise earnings statements for the second and third quarters of 2004 to adjust for a misclassified component in an asset swap with KeySpan Corp 519421, +3.94% The error resulted in the item being classified incorrectly as cash flow. The mistake had no impact on previously reported net cash provided by operating activities, total cash flows, net income or shareholders' equity, according to the company. On Monday the stock of Houston Exploration rose $1.35 to $58.25. Heinz Q2 earns rise, but miss expectations (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- H.J. Heinz Co. HNZ reported fiscal second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $197.3 million, or 56 cents a share, up from $191.5 million, or 54 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 59 cents a share. Gross profit margin declined 1 percentage point to 36.4 percent due primarily to unfavorable raw material and production costs in its European seafood business. Revenue rose 5.2 percent to $2.2 billion. The ketchup maker said it expects fiscal 2005 earnings to be at the low end of prior forecast of $2.32 to $2.42 a share. The stock closed Monday up 95 cents at $38.39. Whitehall Jewelers Q3 loss widens, revenue declines (7:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Whitehall Jewellers, Inc. JWL reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $8.3 million, or 60 cents a share, wider than the loss of $7.4 million, or 53 cents a share in the same period a year ago, due in part to a lower income tax benefit. Revenue fell 4.4 percent to $63.3 million from last year's $66.2 million. The jewelry retailer's stock closed Monday up a penny at $8.65. Global Payment swings to profit on 27% higher revenue (6:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Global Payment Technologies Inc., GPTX, +0.00% a Hauppauge, N.Y., producer of currency-acceptance and verification systems for the gaming, beverage and vending industries, reported fourth-quarter profit compared with a year-earlier loss on 27 percent higher revenue. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, net income was $117,000, or 2 cents a share, against a net loss of $3.9 million, or 70 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue increased to $7.3 million from $5.7 million. GPTX cited higher sales of its Aurora systems for vending and gaming and higher sales of its Argus products to its Australian affiliate. Cost cuts reduced operating expenses 45 percent to $1.6 million. Global Payment shares rose 9 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $5.24 on Monday. Mothers Work posts wider Q4 loss; FY-05 targets set (6:12 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Mothers Work Inc. MWRK posted a net loss of $3.6 million, or 70 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30, a reversal from the retailer's earnings of $1.6 million, or 29 cents, seen in the final three months of fiscal 2003. Quarterly sales slipped 1.1 percent to $121 million, with comparable-store sales down 8.3 percent. According to Thomson First Call, analysts' average forecasts were for a loss of 68 cents per share. "We are cautiously encouraged by our improved sales results thus far in the first quarter of fiscal 2005," said Rebecca Matthias, president and chief operating officer of Mothers Work, adding that management expects the quarter's bottom line to be between breakeven and a loss of 10 cents per share. For fiscal 2005, Mothers Work sees earnings of 70 cents to $1.00 per share on projected sales growth of 9 to 11 percent. Shares of Mothers Work lost 99 cents, or 5.3 percent, to end at $17.57 on Monday. Acambis vaccines lowers rev outlook range for year (2:52 AM ET) LONDON [CBS.MW} -- U.K. vaccines maker Acambis ACAM (UK:ACM)lowered its 2004 revenue guidance range to 80-90 million British pounds from its previous 85-90 million pounds forecast. The company also reported a third quarter pretax loss of 4.5 million pounds; in the third quarter last year it posted a pretax profit of 22.2 million pounds. Acambis said it has also resumed deliveries of its ACAM smallpox vaccine "following lifting of clinical hold by FDA." Great Portland Estates H1 diluted adj NAV up 9% to 305p (2:27 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- British commercial property developer Great Portland Estates(UK:GPOR)said that diluted adjusted net assets per share rose 8.9 percent to 305 pence per share in the first half of its fiscal year. "The West End continues to exhibit healthy signs of recovery, and with occupational take-up rising and the expectation of more robust rental growth returning to the West End in 2005, the prospects for the company are most encouraging," it said. InterContinental Q3 rev. falls 1.1% on dollar, bonuses (2:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- InterContinental Hotels IHG, -2.15% (UK:IHG)said Tuesday that third quarter pre-tax profits rose 4.3 percent to 97 million pounds, while revenue fell 1.1 percent to 563 million pounds, with hotels revenue down 2.6 percent, hit by a weak dollar and bonus payments. Looking forward, it said it was on track to meet its 2004 expectations after a "strong" October, it is "well advanced" on selling Americas hotels and its 500 million pound special dividend will be paid Dec. 17. Its CEO search is "well underway," the company added. UK low-fare Easyjet sees Dec. Q. load flat vs. year-ago (2:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Citing uncertainties on fuel costs and competition, low-fare British airline carrier Easyjet(UK:EZJ)expects the load factor and total revenue per passenger in its December-ending fiscal first quarter to be "broadly the same as last year. We continue to have limited visibility in regard to future fares, however we expect the remaining months of winter to be challenging and that competition will be intense." In the September-ending year, Easyjet said reported profit before tax rose 21 percent to 62.2 million British pounds as revenue rose 17 percent to 1 billion British pounds. Its load factor, a measure of passengers to available seats, improved on the year to 84.5 percent from 84.1 percent. Passenger numbers rose 20 percent on the year to 24.3 million; however, revenue per passenger declined 2 percent to 44.82 pounds "reflecting increased competition," it said. content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Among the shares likely to see active trading in Wednesday's regular session are Google and Hormel Foods. Hormel Foods Corp. HRL, -3.02% is expected to post a fourth-quarter profit of 49 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Goldman Sachs late Tuesday said it has initiated coverage of Google Inc. GOOG, -3.09% stock with a price target of $215. See full story. Wednesday's watch list Analog Devices ADI, -3.23% reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $132.3 million, or 34 cents a share, and sales of $632.1 million. It may declare a special dividend in Dec. 2004 of 30 cents to 45 cents a share, payable on Jan. 2005. CKE Restaurants CKR said that it will restate prior financial reports to correct accounting errors. Revenue for the quarter was $150.5 million, compared with $138.2 million in 2003. Connetics Corp. CNCT, +25.00% said that it has received a non-approvable letter for its drug Extina from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The pharmaceutical company said the FDA concluded that Extina was not effective for the treatment of seborrheic dermatitis, or dandruff, because it was not superior to placebo foam. It said that any potential loss revenue in 2005 from Extina will be offset by not having to incur commercialization costs. As a result of the FDA's letter, Connetics said it now expects fourth-quarter results will come in at the low end of its forecast range of $43 million to $46 million in sales and 16 cents to 18 cents a share in earnings. Corn Products International CPO, -5.71% said that it will close two plants, one in North America and one in South America, in the fourth quarter. Production from the plants will be transferred to facilities in Mexico and Colombia. The closings will result in a one-time fourth-quarter charge of $20.5 million, or 37 cents a share. Dominion Resources D, -0.80% said that it has received approval from the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the District of Maryland to buy three power plants from USGen New England, which is in bankruptcy. It said the purchase price for the Northeast stations is $656 million, including $536 million in cash. It will close the purchase in early 2005. Elan Corp. ELN, +0.00% and Biogen Idec BIIB, -4.19% said that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted an accelerated approval for their multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri. See full story. First Potomac Realty Trust FPO, +0.00% said that it has completed the sale of its Beltsville, Md. property for $8.5 million. The company expects to report a fourth-quarter gain of about $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, on the sale. Fiserv FISV, -1.58% said that its board has authorized a buyback of 8.3 million shares. The repurchase is in addition to the 700,000 remaining shares that may be bought back under the previous 4.9 million share buyback program from 1999. Fred's Inc. FRED, -6.19% said that third-quarter earnings declined from a year earlier as cash-strapped customers purchased lower cost and low-margin merchandise. See full story. Gottschalks GOT, -5.00% narrowed its losses for the third quarter to $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share, from last year's loss of $2.6 million, or 20 cents a share. However, the results were worse than the 8 cents a share loss expected by analysts. Revenue rose to $147.8 million, compared with last year's $145.2 million. See full story. H&R Block HRB, -3.78% reported a fiscal second-quarter net loss of $52.2 million, or 32 cents a share vs. the year-ago earnings of $10.4 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue fell to $539.3 million from $568.8. It said it now expects to earn between $3.50 and $4 a share in its full 2005 fiscal year. See full story. Handleman Co. HDL reported second-quarter earnings of $8.2 million, or 36 cents a share, down 17.6 percent from restated earnings of $9.9 million, or 40 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $295.3 million, up from $269.9 million last year. It also reaffirmed its 2005 earnings from continuing operations forecast of $1.52 to $1.58 a share. Helmerich & Payne HP, -3.83% said that it has sold two of its idle U.S. land well-drilling rigs to an undisclosed foreign entity for $23.9 million. The natural gas and oil well driller said that the sale will result in a first-quarter pre-tax profit of $8.7 million and earnings of 11 cents a share. Integrity Financial Corp. IFCBE said that it has restated its results for the third quarter as a result of increases to its provision for loan losses. It said it now has a third-quarter loss of $1.1 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with a previously reported profit of $1.4 million, or 30 cents a share. It said it increased the loan loss provision to about $4.9 million from $385,000. Koor Industries KOR, +0.00% reported that third-quarter income more than doubled to $3 million, or 10 cents an American Depositary Share, from $1.2 million, or 2 cents an ADS, a year ago. Revenue was $491.2 million vs. $412.8 million a year earlier. Loudeye Corp. LOUD said in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that it plans a 14-million-share offering. It also filed an amended 10-Q filing with the SEC that said it lost 31 cents a share from Jan. through Sept. 2004, not 25 cents a share as had been reported earlier. Standard & Poor's said late Tuesday that it has cut its counterparty credit and senior debt ratings on Marsh & McLennan MMC, -2.71% to "BBB/A-2" from "BBB+/A-2." The insurance broker's cost-cutting plans will take longer than previously expected to take effect, reducing cash flow in 2005 and, to a lesser extent, 2006, S&P said in a statement. Meade Instruments Corp. MEAD said that as a result of lower-than-anticipated third-quarter revenue and continuing softness in sales of its telescope products, it now expects a 2005 net loss of as much as 10 cents a share on revenue between $119 million and $123 million. Previously, it estimated earnings in the range of 5 cents to 15 cents a share on revenue between $125 million and $135 million. Michaels Stores MIK, -1.73% said that it made $42.4 million, or 31 cents a share, for the third quarter, matching Wall Street's expectations. Last year, it earned $38.2 million, or 27 cents a share. It also changed its fourth-quarter expectations to the low end of a range of 74 cents to 76 cents a share. Analysts were expecting a profit of 76 cents a share. See full story. NDCHealth Corp. NDC said that it will take a second-quarter charge of about $2 million, or 3 cents a share, for severance and costs related to the elimination of senior management positions. It forecast net earnings from continuing operations of a penny to 5 cents a share and adjusted earnings from continuing operations of 4 cents to 8 cents a share. Nicor GAS, -3.85% said that its board has voted to terminate the company's existing shareholder rights plan, effective immediately. The board also adopted a new policy to first submit any changes to the poison pill to a shareholder vote, unless the board decides that the submission would not be in the best interest of the company. Oil-Dri Corp. of America ODC, -3.01% said that its first-quarter net earnings were $1.3 million, or 22 cents a share. Last year, the company earned $1.7 million, or 30 cents a share. Revenue fell to $44.1 million from $46.3 million. Possis Medical POSS said that its first-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, but the medical device company lowered its 2005 fiscal outlook as it continues to deal with concerns raised in a study about its treatment for blood clots. See full story. Potlatch Corp. PCH, -0.86% said that it is shutting its Prescott, Ark., sawmill Nov. 20-28. The forest products company said a shortage of logs brought on by exceptionally wet conditions has curtailed logging. Progress Fuel Corp., a subsidiary of Progress Energy PGN, -0.73% said that it will sell some of its oil and gas assets in the Fort Worth, Texas, area for $255 million. It plans to use the proceeds to reduce its debt. SeaChange International SEAC, -4.80% forecast fourth-quarter results below analyst expectations. The provider of servers used in video-on-demand and digital cable said it sees fourth-quarter earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $41 million. Analysts are expecting earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $44 million. Third-quarter earnings were $5.5 million, or 19 cents a share, up from $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share a year ago. Seattle Genetics SGEN, -4.30% said that it has filed a shelf registration statement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $75 million of its common stock. Sigma Designs SIGM, -0.40% said that its third-quarter net earnings were $525,000, or 2 cents a share. Last year, the company earned $149,000, or a penny a share. Revenue fell to $7.7 million from $8.1 million. Analysts estimated a loss of 1 cent a share and revenue of $8 million. The Sports Authority TSA, +3.32% said that for the third quarter it lost $2.2 million, or 9 cents a share, vs. the year-ago loss of $7.6 million , or 31 cents a share. STCR reported a 68 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings. It also announced that Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies will buy it in an all-stock deal valued at $185 million. See full story. Tech Data TECD, -6.02% said that its third-quarter profit rose almost 43 percent from a year ago on increased sales in Europe and the Americas. URS, +1.00% said it has been awarded a contract with the Chicago Public Schools to co-manage its capital improvement program.
